snippet: The country’s cabinet unanimously agreed to fight the $14.5 billion decision, and politicians are expected to debate it next week.

headline.main: Ireland to Appeal Tax Ruling in Apple Case

snippet: The European Commission denies that its shock demand that Apple Inc. hand 13 billion euros in back taxes to Ireland is, in the pungent phrase of Apple CEO Tim Cook, "total political crap".

headline.main: Political? Mais Oui, of Course, EU Insiders Say of Apple Case
headline.print_headline: Political? Mais Oui, of Course, EU Insiders Say of Apple Case

snippet: The world's central banks are "pretty close" to the limits of their ability to stimulate economies, Angel Gurria, head of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), said on Saturday.

headline.main: Central Banks Nearing Limits of Ability to Stimulate Growth-OECD
headline.print_headline: Central Banks Nearing Limits of Ability to Stimulate Growth-OECD

snippet: China and the United States ratified the Paris agreement to cut climate-warming emissions on Saturday, marking a major step toward the enactment of the pact as early as the end of the year and setting the stage for other countries to follow suit.

headline.main: U.S., China Ratify Paris Climate Deal, Setting Stage for G20
headline.print_headline: U.S., China Ratify Paris Climate Deal, Setting Stage for G20

snippet: China and the United States ratified the Paris agreement to cut climate-warming emissions on Saturday, marking a major step toward the enactment of the pact as early as the end of the year and setting the stage for other countries to follow suit.

snippet: Tech companies, civil liberties groups and media organizations are planning to back Microsoft’s resistance to government attempts to snoop on customers.
abstract: Technology companies, civil liberties groups and media organizations file legal briefs supporting Microsoft's case against Justice Dept; lawsuit filed by software firm accuses agency of overusing provision that prevents it from telling customers their electronic communications have been given to law enforcement.

headline.main: Microsoft’s Challenge to Government Secrecy Wins Dozens of Supporters
headline.print_headline: Microsoft’s Legal Challenge to Government Secrecy Wins Dozens of Supporters

snippet: If you find browsing your Twitter feed on a bright white screen is giving you eyestrain at night, try the app’s new setting for the evening hours.

headline.main: Making Twitter Easier to See in the Dark

snippet: Technology, media, pharmaceutical and other companies, along with major corporate lobbying groups, filed legal briefs on Friday in support of a Microsoft Corp lawsuit that aims to strike down a law preventing companies from telling customers the g...

headline.main: Microsoft Gets Support in Gag Order Lawsuit From U.S. Companies
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Gets Support in Gag Order Lawsuit From U.S. Companies

snippet: The NSO Group sells expensive surveillance tools for criminal and terrorism inquiries, but critics say they are also used to track journalists and rights activists.
abstract: Dozens of companies like NSO Group sell surveillance tools that can capture every activity on smartphone, including owner's personal contacts and location; secretive digital surveillance industry is quietly but aggressively marketing such spyware to governments and law enforcement agencies worldwide.

headline.main: How Spy Tech Firms Let Governments See Everything on a Smartphone
headline.print_headline: Phone Spying Is Made Easy. Choose a Plan.

snippet: Mr. Naylor, senior vice president for sales at Hulu, the television streaming service, often travels for work and this year went to a festival in Cannes, France.
abstract: Workspace column features Peter Naylor, senior vice president for sales at Hulu, who describes his daily schedule, office furnishings and work philosophy.

headline.main: Peter Naylor: A Sun-Drenched Cubicle, but Hardly the French Riviera
headline.print_headline: A Cubicle Drenched in Sunlight, but Hardly the French Riviera
